title-group.article-title: Survival outcomes of third molar autotransplantation according to impaction severity: a retrospective cohort study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Conservative Dentistry, Section of Dentistry, Seoul National University Bundang Hospital, Seongnam, Korea
2Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Section of Dentistry, Seoul National University Bundang Hospital, Seongnam, Korea

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Autotransplantation of third molars with complete root formation is a well-established surgical approach for replacing missing teeth, offering biological advantages over conventional prosthetic or implant therapies. The severity of third molar impaction may significantly influence autotransplantation prognosis, yet its clinical significance has not been thoroughly investigated.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This retrospective cohort analysis assessed for autotransplantation of the third molar. Patients were categorized based on impaction severity, and Kaplan–Meier survival analysis was conducted to estimate cumulative Survival rates. Differences in survival according to impaction severity were assessed using the log-rank test, with further evaluation of associated factors.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total 227 autotransplantation patients (118 males, 109 females, 45.4±14.4 years) and the mean follow-up duration was 26.8 months, achieving an overall 5-year cumulative survival rate of 72.0%. Fully impacted teeth exhibited significantly superior survival outcomes (93.3%) compared to fully erupted (62.9%) and partially impacted teeth (82.9%) (P<0.001). Lower patient age was also significantly associated with better survival (P=0.002). Younger age (≤30 years) was also significantly associated with better survival outcomes (P=0.002). No significant survival differences were found regarding sex, splinting period, extra-socket time, or healing period.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Impaction severity is a critical prognostic factor influencing the prognosis of autotransplantation by using the third molars. Comprehensive preoperative evaluation of donor tooth condition, particularly regarding impaction severity, is essential to maximize transplantation outcomes.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: Autotransplantation of teeth is a well-established, biologically advantageous method for reconstructing edentulous areas while preserving natural dentition. Since first described by Miller1 in 1951, autotransplantation has been consistently utilized in clinical dentistry. Despite significant advancements in dental implantology, implants inherently lack periodontal ligament (PDL) structures, and are associated with immediate bundle bone resorption post-extraction, thereby limiting their ability to fully replicate the biological functionality of natural teeth2. Consequently, autotransplantation remains the most ideal approach for restoring aesthetics and function in cases of missing permanent teeth.

The long-term success of autotransplantation critically depends on the presence of vital PDL cells on the root surface at the time of transplantation3. Prognostic factors affecting survival include patient age, condition of the donor tooth, minimally traumatic extraction techniques, recipient socket preparation, extra-alveolar time, and meticulous surgical handling3,4. Precise handling during extraction and stabilization post-transplantation are recognized as critical determinants for favorable clinical outcomes. Previous studies have reported success rates about 80%, even in teeth with fully developed root formation, though success rates are slightly lower compared to teeth with immature roots5,6. Various factors such as patient age, type of donor tooth, surgical technique, and postoperative management have been shown to influence autotransplantation success.

Third molars are commonly utilized in autotransplantation due to their frequent developmental maturity at the time of extraction7. However, when root formation is complete, the potential for pulpal revascularization diminishes8, necessitating endodontic intervention necessary during or shortly after transplantation9,10. On the other hand, third molars also exhibit diverse impaction patterns, ranging from fully erupted to deeply impacted. Most autotransplantation procedures to date have involved fully erupted third molars. Third molars, however, display a spectrum of impaction patterns—from fully erupted to deeply impacted. Fully erupted teeth are generally preferred as donors due to their relative ease of extraction, and as a result, there is limited literature on autotransplantation of severely impacted third molars. Although deeply impacted teeth pose greater technical challenges for atraumatic removal, they tend to maintain superior periodontal health because of reduced exposure to the oral cavity. Therefore, the present retrospective study evaluates clinical outcomes of third molar autotransplantation over a 15-year period, with particular emphasis on the prognostic value of impaction severity in predicting survival outcomes.

sec.title: II. Materials and Methods
sec.p: This retrospective cohort study was conducted in accordance with the ethical standards of the institutional and national research committees and with the Declaration of Helsinki. Ethical approval was obtained from the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Seoul National University Bundang Hospital (IRB No. B-2505-973-104).

This retrospective cohort study included patients who underwent autotransplantation of the third molars between July 2008 and September 2024 at of Section of Dentistry, Seoul National University Bundang Hospital. The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) autotransplantation performed using third molars with fully completed root formation, (2) availability of preoperative radiographic records enabling accurate assessment of impaction severity, and (3) a minimum postoperative follow-up duration of three months.

Impaction severity was categorized into three grades according to the depth of impaction relative to the adjacent alveolar crest and gingival margin: Fully eruption (within soft tissue; the crown was clearly visible without incision), Partial impaction (partial exposure of the crown of third molar; the crown became visible after flap reflection), Fully impaction (complete bony impaction; the crown was not visible even after flap reflection).(Fig. 1) All radiographic and clinical assessments were independently conducted by an experienced oral and maxillofacial surgeon and a conservative dentist. In cases of disagreement, a consensus was reached.

Clinical parameters including sex, age, impaction type, impaction severity, root canal treatment (RCT) timing, extra-socket time, splinting period, and healing time (defined as the time from surgery to functional loading) were collected. Follow-up time was defined as the duration from the functional loading to the last clinical or radiographic evaluation. The primary outcome measure was the survival of transplanted teeth, with failure explicitly defined by the presence of tooth mobility, pain, or periapical pathology requiring extraction. Statistical analyses included descriptive statistics, independent t-tests for continuous variables, and chi-square tests for categorical variables. Kaplan–Meier survival analysis, logistic regression analysis, and interaction tests were performed to identify significant predictors. Statistical significance was set at P<0.05, and all statistical procedures were performed using IBM SPSS Statistics ver. 25.0 (IBM).

sec.title: III. Results
sec.p: A total of 227 third molars with fully completed root development were included in this study.(Table 1) The mean patient age was 45.4±14.4 years, with 118 males (51.98%) and 109 females (48.02%). Impaction severity distribution included 162 fully erupted teeth (71.3%), 35 partially impacted teeth (15.4%), and 30 fully impacted teeth (13.2%).(Fig. 1) The mean extra-alveolar time from extraction to transplantation was 13 minutes 29 seconds±5 minutes 16 seconds. RCT was performed at the time of transplantation in 219 cases (96.5%), involving 3 mm root-end resection using a diamond bur and a #330 tungsten carbide bur, followed by retrograde filling with mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) (ProRoot MTA; Dentsply Sirona).(Fig. 2) RCT was not performed in 7 cases (3.1%), and postoperative RCT was performed within 2 weeks in 6 cases (2.6%). The mean follow-up duration was 26.8 months. During the follow-up period, 67 transplanted teeth failed, resulting in an overall survival rate of 70.5%. The Kaplan–Meier analysis showed overall cumulative survival rates at various intervals. The 1-, 2-, 3-, 4-, and 5-year survival rates were 95.7%, 85.8%, 79.3%, 74.6%, and 72.0%, respectively. Survival probability gradually declined over time, with approximately 80% survival observed at 34.1 months.(Fig. 3) Mean patient age was significantly lower in the survival group (42.74±13.73 years) compared to the failure group (50.19±12.90 years, P<0.001).(Table 2) There were no significant differences between survival and failure groups with respect to sex, extra-socket time, splinting or healing duration.

With regarding to the impaction severity, patients were classified into three groups according to the type of impaction.(Table 3) When stratified by impaction severity, the 5-year cumulative survival rates were 62.9% for fully erupted teeth, 82.9% for partially impacted teeth, and 93.3% for fully impacted teeth (P<0.001). Fully erupted teeth had the highest mean patient age and the longest follow-up duration; however, fully impacted teeth consistently exhibited the highest survival rates throughout all follow-up intervals.(Fig. 2) Kaplan–Meier survival curves demonstrated significantly superior survival for fully impacted teeth compared to partially impacted and fully erupted teeth (log-rank test, P<0.001).

Patients were further categorized into three age groups: ≤30 years, 31-45 years, and >45 years. The 5-year cumulative survival rates for these age groups were 90.7%, 68.8%, and 63.2%, respectively (P=0.002). Notably, the ≤30-year group consistently maintained high survival from the first to fifth year (90.7%), whereas survival progressively declined in the 31-year to 45-year and >45-year groups (68.8% and 63.2%, respectively).

sec.title: IV. Discussion
sec.p: This study identified impaction severity as a significant prognostic factor influencing the survival of autotransplanted third molars. Specifically, fully impacted third molars demonstrated superior long-term survival rates compared to partially impacted or fully erupted teeth. This trend, corroborated by Kaplan–Meier analysis, suggests that impaction severity is not merely a surgical technicality but rather a biologically and prognostically meaningful factor.

The most critical factor determining prognosis in tooth autotransplantation is PDL reattachment. Various surgical techniques have been proposed to minimize trauma to root surfaces, including the use of specialized instruments, preoperative orthodontic forces, and ostectomy procedures11-14. However, the severity of third molar impaction has not been thoroughly considered in existing protocols. Our findings align with previous research suggesting that deeply impacted third molars may possess healthier PDL tissues due to reduced exposure to the oral environment15, thereby enhancing their potential for successful transplantation. Clinically, these results imply that criteria for donor tooth selection may require revision. Traditional methods favor teeth easier to extract surgically, whereas our results indicate that more deeply impacted third molars—though surgically challenging—may offer superior biological conditions as donor teeth. Nevertheless, increased impaction depth raises risks for surgical complications, extended extraction duration, and difficulty in root preservation16,17. Therefore, bone removal and the use of surgical instruments such as elevators or luxators should be limited strictly to the crown area above the cementoenamel junction to minimize trauma to the PDL. Moreover, third molars often exhibit anatomical complexities in roots and root canals, complicating endodontic treatment18,19. Therefore, collaboration between oral and maxillofacial surgeons and endodontic specialists is recommended when planning autotransplantation with deeply impacted third molars.

To maintain PDL cell viability, transplantation within 18 minutes is crucial8,20. In this study, the mean extraoral time was approximately 13 minutes and 29 seconds. Given the complex anatomical variations of third molar root canals, retrograde root canal therapy performed extraorally is advocated18,19. Intraoperative retrograde canal filling achieved canal sealing in 96.5% of our cases. However, in instances requiring extended extraoral periods due to extensive site preparation, intraoperative endodontic treatment was occasionally omitted to protect PDL viability. Andreasen et al.21 reported that approximately 15% of teeth with closed apices regained vitality following transplantation. Consistent with this, in our study, five patients developed tertiary dentin and remained asymptomatic without postoperative endodontic treatment. Although not statistically significant, there were no failures among cases either untreated or treated endodontically post-transplantation, underscoring the need for further investigation into optimal timing and necessity of endodontic interventions.

Patient age also emerged as a statistically significant predictor of transplant success. The role of age observed in our study is consistent with previous findings indicating superior periodontal healing potential in younger individuals22. The viability and regenerative capacity of PDL fibroblasts and stem cells decrease with advancing age, likely contributing to the significantly better survival outcomes observed in patients aged ≤30 years compared with older cohorts. This observation aligns with prior evidence demonstrating age-related declines in regenerative capacities of periodontal tissues23. These findings further support the notion that the biological and anatomical characteristics of donor teeth are more critical to transplantation success than perioperative management factors5. This suggests that preoperative tooth condition and inherent biological factors may exert a more profound influence on outcomes than operative procedures.

Several limitations of this study must be acknowledged. Firstly, the retrospective design inherently carries a risk of selection bias. Secondly, while the follow-up duration was adequate for evaluating mid-term survival, longer follow-up is necessary to assess long-term periodontal stability and functional outcomes comprehensively. Thirdly, despite efforts to standardize the assessment of impaction severity, variability in radiographic interpretation could not be completely excluded. The retrospective nature of this investigation and its reliance on radiographic assessment introduce additional limitations, such as potential biases in patient selection and variability in evaluating impaction severity. Future prospective studies employing standardized diagnostic criteria, uniform surgical protocols, and extended follow-up periods are essential to validate these findings and further elucidate the role of impaction severity in the outcomes of third molar autotransplantation including the influence of recipient site bone quality, systemic health, and oral hygiene.

sec.title: V. Conclusion
sec.p: Impaction severity significantly affected the survival outcomes of autotransplanted mature third molars, with fully impacted teeth demonstrating the highest success rates. Younger patient age was also associated with better survival, highlighting the importance of biological factors in prognosis. Careful preoperative assessment of donor tooth condition, especially impaction severity, is critical to optimize transplantation success.

fn.p: K.H.L. participated in data collection and writing the manuscript. Y.S.C., P.Y.Y., and J.Y.Y. participated in the study design and performed the statistical analysis. J.K.K. participated in the study design and coordination and helped to draft the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

p.bold: Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate

fn.p: This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Seoul National University Bundang Hospital (IRB No. B-2505-973-104), and was conducted according to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki for research on humans. Informed consent was not applicable due to the retrospective nature of the study.
No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.

caption.p: Representative case of transplantation according to the impaction severity (fully eruption; A-E, partial impaction; F-J, fully impaction; K-O). A. Preoperative radiography for transplantation of fully erupted #18 to #16. B. Extraction of advanced caries tooth and site preparation. C. Transplantation and fixed with suture. D. Root canal treatment after 2 weeks. E. Postoperative 19 months after the functional loading. F, G. Preoperative radiography for transplantation of partially impacted #18 to #46. H. Transplantation and fixed with suture. I. Immediate postoperative radiograph. J. Postoperative 12 months after the functional loading. K. Preoperative radiography for transplantation of #48 to #47. L. Extraction of root resorption tooth and exposure of the fully impacted third molar. M. Transplantation and fixed with suture and resin-wire splinting. N. Immediate postoperative radiograph. O. Postoperative 9 months after the functional loading.
An intraoperative photograph of apicoectomy and retrograde filling with mineral trioxide aggregate.
